I've run out of time! I went with the easy answer.
Necessity for salvation; Romans 3:23, all are in need of forgiveness for sinning against God. 
What we are saved from; I have been saved from the consequence of sin, which is death. (Romans 6:23), I am being saved from the power of sin in my life (Romans 8:5-8), I will be saved from the hold of sin on my life permanently and into the full conformity of Jesus.
Faith and works; We are saved by grace through faith (Ephesians 2:8) This is not a thing that we can do, or could have done, it is imparted to us by God as a gift. No human activity can bring about reconciliation with God. Man sins against a perfect infinite God, the only one worthy and powerful enough to pay such a debt and ransom us would be a perfect and infinite God. Salvation is not a lawless state (TEE 2:114), by no means, Paul gathers all people together as condemned and guilty in the early chapters of Romans, he describes the work and price paid by Christ in the later chapters, and in Chapter 12 he sums things up saying we should offer our bodies as a living sacrifice by the mercies of God, which he outlined in the earlier chapters of Romans. Offering our lives as living sacrifices is our spiritual act of service, or as some translations say it, our reasonable (in light of what God has done) act of service (Amplified, KJV). Faith without the evidence of works cannot be said to be real faith at all Ephesians 2:10, James 2:14). 
Adoption; We are children of God by adoption through the work of Christ (Galatians 4).
